1764.text: I do believe that because the text is there

1769.text: anyone can go and do their version.

1771.text: I know we've made bold choices

1773.text: and we've cut things and we've rearranged things,

1775.text: but that's our version now in Chichester tonight.

1780.text: People can go off and do their version,

1783.text: it's there for them to work on

1785.text: and to create their take on it.

1789.text: You've talked about the precision of the comedic moments.

1793.text: (in order) to get the good laughs.

1795.text: I'm just wondering how you also balance that with

1799.text: so that every night the play feels new and feels alive.

1808.text: I believe that part of being professional as an actor is

1814.text: re-creating something night after night and making it feel fresh.

1819.text: When you've got actors of this sort of calibre

1823.text: they are all very good at doing that.

1826.text: Surprisingly it's not really an issue.

1829.text: I don't even have to discuss it with them.

1832.text: They have the ability to completely live in it in the moment every single time.

1838.text: I always feel that if I discussed it with them

1841.text: it might make them self conscious about what they're doing.

1844.text: I suppose there is an advantage in the fact that we love it so much.

1849.text: I will very happily laugh along in rehearsal at the comic stuff.

1854.text: I also try and be as objective as I can

1861.text: Because sometimes I will laugh at things that one of the actors does

1865.text: because I know the actor and it makes me laugh that

1867.text: he's slipped over and fallen on his face or whatever he's done.

1871.text: Then I'm laughing at him rather than the character.

1874.text: I would say; "That was hilarious but we shouldn't do that in the show".

1877.text: You're constantly trying to negotiate your way around that.

1881.text: I try to make the rehearsal room as much fun as I can.

1885.text: If it's fun, people can invent and dare to fall on their face

1889.text: and say "God that was crazy, I shoudn't have done that".

1895.text: They can make fools of themselves and who cares?

1898.text: Some of the best ideas come from people doing quite bold things.

1901.text: You might say; "Well that was too much but we could do is this."

1906.text: I'm afraid I'm going to have to bring it to a close. It's a shame, I know!

1911.text: For those of you who live in Chichester there will be the post-show talk with members of the company.

1919.text: That will be on Monday 24th October.

1922.text: For many of you who have been supporting the theatre, not just this year

1925.text: but for all of the seasons with Alan & Jonathan,

1928.text: this Saturday morning at 11.00 am in here

1931.text: I'll be doing "Question Time" with Jonathan and Alan.

1934.text: I'll be asking about the whole of their time here,

1938.text: the things that they wish had gone slightly differently,

1941.text: their highs and lows I suppose, very few lows!

1944.text: Chris, the final thing to say is,

1947.text: because this is the last production of an incredible period of time at Chichester Festival Theatre,

1953.text: for my money I cannot imagine seeing a better version of

1958.text: I think they are absolutely wonderful.

1960.text: With regard to the gentleman's lovely question about Shakespeare,

1963.text: we walked up the park on Saturday as the sun was setting, my husband & I,

1967.text: and my husband said: "You know, I think Shakespeare would have been happy with that!"
